author: mikemaccana
body:
Steps to reproduce
------------------

Start Powershell 6.2 preview 2


Expected behavior
-----------------

A cursor should appear at the end of the prompt.

Actual behavior
---------------

Cursor is missing.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/172594/40723045-d4b40130-6415-11e8-872e-8f5f9516433b.png)


Environment data
----------------


```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.1.0-preview.2
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    v6.1.0-preview.2
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.17677
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0

```

Note starting Powershell 5 shows the normal `_` cursor.

comments.author: lzybkr
comments.body:
You can check the property `[Console]::CursorVisible`, it's probably `false`, setting it to `true` should help.

Are you using `PSReadLine 2.0.0-beta1`? In that version, I started hiding the cursor while rendering to fix the flashes people see on Linux/Mac, but nobody has reported any similar issue and I've never noticed any problems.

comments.author: MaximoTrinidad
comments.body:
@mikemaccana , @lzybkr 

At least in PowerShell Core, I would recommend to uninstall PSReadline (which is a pain to do), then remove/reinstall PowerShell Core.   This is to get back the non-Beta PSReadline with PowerShell Core.

This way we can truly confirm the issue.  Now, if the Beta has been installed on Windows PowerShell, then I'm not sure how fix that one.
:P

comments.author: mikemaccana
comments.body:
Hey @MaximoTrinidad - just wanted to respond re: uninstalling PSReadline. https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/powershell/2018/01/24/powershell-core-6-1-roadmap/ mentions:

> Some of my engineers will be spending time contributing to this project to get it to production quality so we can include it in PowerShell Core 6.0.

So I thought PSReadLine 2.0.0-beta1 was installed by Powershell 6.1 Preview 2.  Is this incorrect? I certainly don't remember installing it myself.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @mikemaccana PSCore6 still currently ships with PSReadLine 1.2 due to an issue in PSReadLine 2.0.  The issue has since been fixed, but the fix isn't available until the next PSReadLine beta release.  You would have had to manually install PSReadLine 2.0.
